reviewText: This game is suprisingly good,  at first impressions I thought it was going to be a badly put together story and ganeplay, oh how wrong was I!!. Jolly rover reminds me a lot of the monkey island series. The graphics are retro styled and work well with the whole layout of the ganeplay itself. It is narrated throughout which is great as the voices add to the fun of playng, Its not a huge world based game. It has a few locations and three main islands with many explorable parts, not a huge amount of interacable characters but this to me stops it getting boring and clustered. The story is good and the puzzles are fun and not too hard. It is a light ha=earted game but worthy of a 9/10 I would recommend to anyone who wants a casual easy flowing game. If you enjoy click and points give it a try and for the price you cannot lose.

reviewText: This game was a great throwback to classing adventure games and rarely did I feel completely unable to figure something out.  Liked the voice acting and the animation a lot. Had a few adultish jokes in there that I was happy to see to keep the game from getting too kiddy on me.  Ended up a little short but that made for a fun adventure that didn't overstay it's welcome.  If you liked Monkey Island you might like Jolly Rover.

reviewText: At first glance this game will look like some sort of Monkey Island ripoff. And in a way, that might be the way to describe it. Personally, I think it's more of a love letter to adventure games of yesteryear, combining the atmosphere and humor typical of major adventure games of the 90s with a few modern twists, including quests to find hidden pieces of eight and crackers, and a clever hint system should you choose to use it. If there's one thing that I dislike about many modern adventure games, it's that they give hints much too easily. Making the puzzles difficult to solve and not forcing hints down your throat is better for an adventuring experience.\nThe developer commentary is quite fun and at times hilarious to listen to, ranging from anecdotes on the game's development to outtakes from the voice artists. (Be on the lookout for Janes singing Party In The USA!") The addition of unlockable character profiles and artwork does feel like an attempt to put in some artificial replay value
date: but that's really my only major complaint with the game.\nOverall
recommended: if you want a short but sweet ride through a colorful world created as an homage to 90s adventures
hoursPlayed: I recommend giving this game a shot."
votesTotal: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm ashamed. I've begun playing the game in... 2012. Since then, it's been waiting to be finished.

Well, I did. Three years after.

Jolly Rover is a story about a dog that is a sailor and become a pirate because of an evil governor. Here's Gaius James Rover becoming Jolly Rover, specialized in freeing people, in using Voodoo spells and... in juggling.

The plot is nice, that's sure, though you're still asking yourself how Gaius became a sailor when he wanted to be a clown. Anyway, you have the traditional story family, the voodoo, the cannibals, the lady pirates...

The graphics are aimed to a young audience: it's colorful, in style with old cartoons that could have been broadcasted during my childhood and they're well done. Everything is easy to understand (well, if you're an English native speaker or skilled in the language, else, you may have an hard time to find what to do).

The dialogues are also good, with humor or naivity. Even the voice acting is quite good.

The gameplay is a traditional adventure game: discussing is giving you clues, observing objects can be rewarding, well, it's a good trip to memories with old titles of the same genre.

No, really, Jolly Rover is well-polished, well-balanced and adapted to a young audience. Recommending it with all my heart.
voteText: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: Jolly Rover is a fun little classic point & click style adventure game. You play as James Rover, a dog who wants to be a clown but ends up becoming a pirate (yaaaar!). if you are familiar with this genre, then you probably know exactly what to expect - the game isn't breaking any huge molds. But what it does, it does well. None of the puzzles are too hard - if anything, most are too easy - but I thought the difficulty balance was OK (there is even a hint system available if you do get stuck). The game is also very short (5 hours or so). But if you are a fan of this genre, I think you should give it a go. The graphics are nice (though the lack of a hi-res option is lamentable), and the dialogue and voice work are good. The game is pretty funny as well. But it's definitely not for everyone. I wholly recommend it to anyone, like me, who cut their teeth on classic Sierra and Lucasarts adventure games. For anyone else, it might not be up your alley... but I do think it's worth checking out.

reviewText: the idea of pirate dogs didn‚Äôt particularly catch my interest, but i heard jolly rover was pretty good.  it doesn‚Äôt take itself seriously and doesn‚Äôt have the most interesting story, but the puzzles and art are really nice.  sometimes the silliness is entertaining ‚Äî i especially enjoyed watching the current quest update during dialog.  while it sometimes could have done more to point me in the right direction, most of the puzzles were intuitive and satisfying.  there are also plenty of crackers around to feed to your all-knowing parrot in turn for more useful hints.\n\ni definitely recommend jolly rover to adventure game fans as well as anyone who would consider playing an adventure game.  while the cartoon-dog style might make you think it‚Äôs appropriate for children, there are a couple things you might want to know:  it says ‚Äú‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•es‚Äù (in the female dogs context) once and has some sexual connotations that most children probably wouldn‚Äôt notice.

reviewText:
I'd heard good things about this point and click adventure game, so I decided to try it out. I played it during my lunch breaks at work and found it to be quite enjoyable. It recalls fond memories of The Secret of Monkey Island, one of my favorite games of all time.

Puzzles were mostly simple, though I'll admit I had to feed Juan the parrot a few crackers for hints on occasion. A few nice ideas streamlined the experience. First of all, holding down the Space Bar would highlight objects around the room that you could interact with. Also, the color of text hovering over objects changes color only if a new reaction will result.

The game has a fun sense of humor, and for some unknown reason I feel that pirates and dogs make a great combination.

I highly recommended Jolly Rover to classic point and click adventure game fans, especially those fond of the Monkey Island series.

reviewText: If you like dogs and pirates and dogs who are pirates, your in luck as this game has all of the above in spades. The game follows the story of  Gauius James Rover a swashbuckling sausage-dog  who is the, son of the famous clown Jolly Rover, who died from a blow to the groin from an improperly loaded joke cannon. You know that old chestnut. A funny, highly entertaining point and click adventure game, buy it.

Unexpectedly good. Got this for $1 in one of the indie paks in christmas, and it really is a very competent point & click, with several additions that enhance the genre. It rewards obsessive clickers with collectibles, and highlights the name of items that you can interact with, and if u tried a particular interaction earlier, the game lets you know by making the text white (as opposed to blue, which indicates a new interaction). It also has a scoring/title system (which I assume is based on how fast you solve puzzles + how many collectibles you get).. it's not much but it's there. Lots of dog puns.\n\nTired of the pirates theme though. Should've left that to Monkey Island.
FURRY MONKEY ISLAND\n\nWHAT MORE COULD YOU ASK FOR!?

reviewText: An incredible masterpiece. At the first glance, nothing too impressive. Mediocre puzzles and old challenges might not impress, however the atmosphere and the humour counts for it all. The game is short, however, took me 5 hours to complete. But knowing the price and the quality of Jolly Rover its worth it. reviewText:
Simple, cute, amusing point and click.  Fun story and characters.  I loved playing it.

Scale: 1=despised 2=negative 3=could go either way 4=positive 5=loved

Game design: 4/5 The game is really tight and everything works well.  However, there are some extra things needed for 100% that you really have to guess at to accomplish.  You need to click everything in every scene twice before you move on to a new area of story because you can't go back, and that doesn't guarantee that you'll find everything because there's no reason for a lot of it.  It adds a little replayability because it's a short game, but that's a cheap tactic.

Tone: 5/5 Fun.  Cartoony.  Pirates.  Great things working great together.

Personal skew: 4/5 This is a pretty easy and short game.  If you are a hardcore point & click gamer who wants a challenge and for some reason you paid full price for this game, you'll probably feel pretty ripped off.  But for me this game was great fun.

reviewText: This is a point and click adventure game.  If you liked games like Monkey Island, sure you will reasonably enjoy it.  Replay value is very limited unless you missed some of the achievements.  The voice acting was good, the puzzles were simple.  Its a game you play when you have played all the greats already.  Honestly I bought this game on sale, Its filler something you play between waiting for the return of the golden age of classic point of clicks. Which sadly is never going to come back again.  I enjoyed it.  It made me miss my old adventure games.  If you can get it on sale I'd reccomend it.

reviewText:
A very short game. The game was also only about 4 hours long start to finish.
Jolly Rover is a Point 'n Click Adventure game which is similar to the Monkey Island series except every characters are dogs and puppies.
The puzzles are clever and not confusing at all. Most of them could be figured out without having to look up for guides as they are not random as other bad PnC Adventure games (e.g. Strong Bad).
The dialogues are humurous and are the best part of the game, but also the weakest part. The game does not do anything extra ordinary, but it does wrap up the elements of a good PnC Adventure game pretty well.
If you are a fan of PnC Adventure games, it's worth to pick up for a cheap price.

reviewText: Jolly rover is a fun click adventure game that includes the brilliant aspects of puzzles along with a well thought out storyline. The game is full of strange and bizarre characters; all of them are well voice acted and memorable. The game doesn‚Äôt cut corners when it comes to visual art either, the style feels unified and not out of place. The puzzle selections are diverse but sadly the game demands a too specific way to win. There are no branching storyline in this game. The developers clearly intended for that to happen because they included a talking parrot to guide the players in the event they are stuck. The game flows perfectly and the witty storyline fits in very well with the puzzles. Overall pretty average game, not nearly as good as Myst but not nearly as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• as the other indie puzzle clicker games. For 5 dollars or less you get around 5 hours of entertainment, not too shabby at all!

reviewText:
Voice acting, animation, and writing. Totally unnecessary!

When your lead role is played by a watered down witless Gybrush Threepwood you may think you're hosed. This is all saved by the fact he is a dog.

Creative game play is absent completely. But its all ok. The arbitrary fetch quest is appropriate..... because your a dog.

He has a deep and meaningful romance with a woman. Its totally not forced and creepy...... because your a dog.

If you can't tell that there are better indie adventures available like puzzle agent. You just may be a dog to.

reviewText: Jolly Rover is a perfect example of everything that stinks about adventure games.\n\nThe solutions to the puzzles don't always make logical sense; you find yourself just clicking wildly on every item and every square inch of each room until you solve" the puzzle. reviewText: Do you find yourself wishing that Sam and Max had annoying voice acting? Do you find yourself wishing that Sam and Max didn't have such sharp wit? Are you the sort of easily-amused dimwit who claps your hands and squeals with glee whenever you see a pirate? Then by gum you'll love this really annoying game.\n\nN.B.: A lot of time and care seems to have gone into the making of this game and it's technically very slick. But a lovingly-arranged bouquet of broccoli and dog turds is still a bouquet of broccoli and dog turds.

reviewText: The art style and the dialog at the beginning of the game make it almost feel like it should be lumped in with young children games like Putt Putt and Pajama Sam (which, for their targeted age group, are awesome in their own right) but once you start getting into the meat of the story you'll find puzzles and plot that any fan of Monkey Island or Sam&Max series should love.
I F***ING LOVE this game, one of my favourite point n clicks, nice humor, suitable for everyone, and it feels piratey/adventurey, the best of feelings!
Brilliant adventure game and hilarious all the way through.\nMuch in the vein of the Broken Sword trilogy.\nHighly recommended if you like adventure games.
A nice puzzle adventure for both newcomers and veterans to the genre
When I want my dog to know what Monkey Island is like, I let her watch me play this.

Corny cheesy fun, not as whitty as your more traditional Monkey Island games, but definately a good ol' 'bout of piratey fun. Not too long in gameplay, and the majority of puzzles are fairly easy and amusing.



Word of warning: avoid speaking to your tattered parrot familiar at all costs, as he will regularly ruin gameplay and give things away without you even asking!
very entertaining, very short (5hrs gameplay). it's a secret of monkey island clone, but in a good way.
Surprisingly good indie adventure.
This is something i never wouldve even given consideration to had i not recieved a free key. but this is a fantastic little gem of a game, great humour, great puzzles, highly recommend!

This game is a homage to the Secrets of Monkey Island -- some people will find it too derivative but I enjoyed seeing a different take on the same genre. The puzzles were generally straightforward, and there is an ingame hint system if you need it.\n\nThere are better adventure games out there (Daedalic), but if you are looking for more, this one is not bad.

A poor man's Monkey Island. The voice acting and animations are charming. The game is not too hard, and would be a good introduction for someone interested in point and click games. Very cute and very fun.
Awesome adventure game. Really funny dialog and great voice acting.
Heyyo, an indie adventure game with dogs... pretty good.
A fun little game; plenty of puns and charming scenery. Point and click adventure games are a personal favorite of mine.

Shades of Monkey Island here, what with the pirate theme, but the writing isn't quite as funny or clever. Story's rather short. The puzzles aren't terribly difficult, but finding all the collectibles (achievements) is. Bright spot: voice acting.
It's fun if you like that sort of thing.

This is a point and click adventure game with silly dialog. It's a clear homage to the Monkey Island series, so if you want a light-hearted game to pass some time, and you loved Monkey Island, this is a great game to pick up.
This is an adventure game chock full of charm and wit.  Excellent music, pleasant art, and my goodness, is James adorable!

While not up to the standards of Monkey Island, the levels of writing and wit in this game are surprisingly high. It's a good adventure that's fairly child-safe, as they probably won't get the occasional adult joke. It has good voice acting, fun characters, cute art, and the built in hint system counters the occasional inobvious puzzle. The only real complaint I have is that it's so darn short; you can beat it in a single sitting with ease, and there's not much replay value unless you just like farming steam achievements with a walkthrough on hand.

Sometimes a little too cutesy, sometimes a little too easy, but lots of fun, quirky, and a fling back to the good old days of adventure puzzle games (plus I went to school with one of the voice actors).

I enjoyed this point and click much more than I thought I would.  The hint system I was very impressed with.  You can get just a little hint or have the whole puzzle blown open because it's been driving you mad.  Good story and very intuitive puzzles. Gaius is most certainly the next Threepwood.

So I know this game doesn't necessarily push the bounds of game design - in fact one could argue that the story isn't all that original either - but it does give an interesting twist to a familiar tail tale. The reason this game stands out and the reason why I love it is because it combines story, puzzle solving and ridiculously silly humour involving an over-abundance of canine puns. It's just plain fun. Definitely worth your cash monies.
I F***ING LOVE this game, one of my favourite point n clicks, nice humor, suitable for everyone, and it feels piratey/adventurey, the best of feelings!

The art style and the dialog at the beginning of the game make it almost feel like it should be lumped in with young children games like Putt Putt and Pajama Sam (which, for their targeted age group, are awesome in their own right) but once you start getting into the meat of the story you'll find puzzles and plot that any fan of Monkey Island or Sam&Max series should love.

Shades of Monkey Island here, what with the pirate theme, but the writing isn't quite as funny or clever. Story's rather short. The puzzles aren't terribly difficult, but finding all the collectibles (achievements) is. Bright spot: voice acting.
It's fun if you like that sort of thing.

Great light and fun adventure game! Recommended to anyone who likes a little bit of challenge, but also likes if there are hints around to help them out. Had a ton of fun with this, great way to spend the five or so hours it'll take you to complete it!
This is a truly awesome little adventure game.  The best I've ever played of this genre.  A bit short, but I say the developers commentary balances that out.

A game for all ages to play. I especially found the in game guide/hints were very appropriate. The story could have used some work,but the puzzles were very simple to figure out as long as you found all the keys. It was a good 6 hours. 7/10
A great relaxing puzzle with pirates and parrots and voodoo.

A pretty good adventure game.
The voice acting isn't the greatest, and the game only runs in 800x600, but those are the only downsides that stand out for me, and they're not dealbreakers.
It's not very long. I completed my first playthrough in a bit over 4 hours, and I didn't rush through at all. I don't think this is a bad thing, it keeps the story focussed, without too many sidequests and distractions.
There's also plenty of hidden goodies to find, but if you're a good adventure player you'll already click on everything, so it shouldn't be too hard to find at least most of them. Still, it's a nice addition.
Don't be put off by the dogs. A few puns aside, they could as easily have used humans.

Overall, if you even slightly like adventure games, it's worth the price.

This point and click adventure took me about 3 or 4 hours to finish. I tried not to cheat or get hints and only needed to twice.

Overall good for what it is, and it was amusing... however at times it was also typical of point and click... sometimes you just combine things to combine them without any logic.

The dialog had voice actors so at least it wasn't all reading.  Not bad and casual for those who like this kind of thing.
Clever little adventure game with a nice score, funny writing, puzzles that never get obscure, and one hell of an awesome parrot. Also, lots of crackers.
Even though it looks like a Monkey Island knockoff, it's actually pretty good on its own. If you like the Monkey Island games, it's worth a shot.

Not bad, but not great. It's a point and click adventure and it mirrors Monkey Island extremely closely. It does have some unique mechanics of its own such as three types of in game collectives which unlock concept art etc. one of which is used as a currency for the hint system.
Really Enjoyable Point & Click Adventure
Jolly Rover is point and click" Game.\nYou can combine some item to each other or use Voodoo's magic to solve puzzles.\nIt has some gag and moderate fun. (7.0/10)"
This is an awesome game for adventure gamers, really made me nostalgic for the old Lucasarts SCUMM games.

Escape from monkey island for furries...
not a bad game actually,it's classic point and click adventure game.
You need to click on objects and  interact with characters and utilize your inventory
in creative ways to advance through the game.
Pirates! Hooray!
Basically what the store page says. Nice little point and click, and humorous to boot. If you love the traditional-style point and click adventures, play this today!

Jolly Rover is that kind of game that starts off slowly, gets a lot better the further you progress into it, but never becomes truly great. However, it still holds itself well in the adventure gaming market, with lots of impressive visual detail in its backgrounds and character animations.

Item interactions and puzzles are very often straight-forward and obvious, though a few are actually truly clever. There is voodoo magic that you learn throughout the game by mixing various symbols together, and is used pretty well as a puzzle mechanic without ever becoming overly complex.

I enjoyed this mostly for the story and animation. While the puzzles weren't great, they never felt out-of-place or too simple, and I feel the experience as a whole made for a very solid adventure game.

3 out of 5 foxes.
Nice story. Nice gameplay.

Monkey Island with a dog pirate. Cutest game ever.

meh thought this game would have been better. but it only hooked me about 30 mins.
This is a truly awesome little adventure game.  The best I've ever played of this genre.  A bit short, but I say the developers commentary balances that out.

Great light and fun adventure game! Recommended to anyone who likes a little bit of challenge, but also likes if there are hints around to help them out. Had a ton of fun with this, great way to spend the five or so hours it'll take you to complete it!

So I know this game doesn't necessarily push the bounds of game design - in fact one could argue that the story isn't all that original either - but it does give an interesting twist to a familiar tail tale. The reason this game stands out and the reason why I love it is because it combines story, puzzle solving and ridiculously silly humour involving an over-abundance of canine puns. A highly accessible and highly enjoyable point and click adventure game. On top of that, it has excellent voice acting and a hilarious script, and its hint system gives even the dumbest of adventurers a fighting chance.

Corny cheesy fun, not as whitty as your more traditional Monkey Island games, but definately a good ol' 'bout of piratey fun. Not too long in gameplay, and the majority of puzzles are fairly easy and amusing.

It may not be one of the best point and click adventures but this is one of my personal favourites. if you're a fan of monkey island or just any point and click i recommend this (really fun to play). 4.5/5 pirate dogs

Just finished this game and I immediately started playing it from the start with the commentary on. Jolly Rover is a very cute, immersive,  and well written/ performed game where you do all kinds of things as a pirate. It is a relatively long game and, thanks to the flexible helping system, is recommended to both beginners and experts in this particular genre. Buy it. Play it. And something third :D
On sale for ¬£1.50, Jolly Rover is a reasonable Monkey Island clone with a decent sense of humour. It's a little childish but for this price, grab it.

A short but pretty good Monkey Island with dogs, this one's worth your money not least because an Aussie developer made it.

It's a pretty traditional adventure game with inventory puzzles and the like but it does its best to differentiate itself and avoide some of the trappings which annoy me so much about the genre. First and foremost, is that you change the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing speed at which your main character walks. Secondly, there's a really good hint system at work ranging from vague to explicit instructions and really helped alleviate the frustration which inevitably comes upon you when you can't work out what to do.

A pretty cool collectible system which rewards you with concept art and music and a developer's commentary which I've yet to listen to when you finish the game.

I think I got this for $5 when it was on special. Worth that if this is you're genre. A little short but very charming.

A pretty good adventure game.
The voice acting isn't the greatest, and the game only runs in 800x600, but those are the only downsides that stand out for me, and they're not dealbreakers.
It's not very long. I completed my first playthrough in a bit over 4 hours, and I didn't rush through at all. I don't think this is a bad thing, it keeps the story focussed, without too many sidequests and distractions.
There's also plenty of hidden goodies to find, but if you're a good adventure player you'll already click on everything, so it shouldn't be too hard to find at least most of them. Still, it's a nice addition.
Don't be put off by the dogs. A few puns aside, they could as easily have used humans.

Overall, if you even slightly like adventure games, it's worth the price.

This point and click adventure took me about 3 or 4 hours to finish. I tried not to cheat or get hints and only needed to twice.

Overall good for what it is, and it was amusing... however at times it was also typical of point and click... sometimes you just combine things to combine them without any logic.

game is so so  for the money spent at one point in game it becomes to diifucult to navigate through map graphics story line is good

A charming point-and-click adventure worthy of passing the time. It's quirky characters and innovative hint system will appeal to veterans and newbies of adventure games, but the appearance of some lazy puzzles and less-than-spectacular scriptwriting will only keep this title on the general average.
Good interesting puzzle game. Yes, you'll get stuck but perserve there is a simple solution you have overlooked.
If you like adventure games like Sam and Max, Grim Fandango, Monkey Island... stop reading this and BUY THIS GAME!

A fantastic point-and-click adventure with intuitive puzzles, great voice-acting, a huge number of branching choices, tons of collectables, and genuine humor. I can't recommend this enough! Monkey Island would be proud.

I enjoyed this game.  Graphics are quite pleasant, the voice acting is good, and it plays like it should.   I didn't find any game breaking bugs or any bugs that I recall.  I did get stuck in a couple areas for a while, though I was sure I tried the one thing that did work already before I looked it up.

All the good things said, it's short.  It doesn't take long to go through it, even with taking a while to figure something out.  The blacksmith shop should definitely have been used for something given the amount of detail that was put into it.

It is also fairly easy, but that is as good as it is bad.

If they made a Jolly Rover 2, I would buy it.
This game offers good laughs, some clever puzzles and hell of a good time, all for a very reasonable price. Ye'd be a fool not to check this one out.\n\nI wouldn't mind a sequel, too!
Brings back the good memories. A proper point & click adventure game with charming graphics, funny dialog and crazy but solvable puzzles. Just like they used to make them.
DO NOT BUY.\n\nWhile the game has some interesting elements and occasionally hilarious dialogue, the cons outweigh the pros. The organic
date: intuitive" hint system is arbitrary at best
recommended: providing least help for difficult puzzles and excessive help for easy ones. It's also incapable of telling how much you have already solved.\n\nMuch worse than that is the terrible handling of an extremely interesting plot. Aside from terrible pacing and difficulty knowing where to go next at times for story progression
hoursPlayed: the most important and crucial revelations are revealed through sudden
voteText:
unexpected dialogue options or unintuitive question choices. Solemn and important scenes are switched into humor or blase gameplay so quickly that you have no time to process the emotional signifigance. Certain questions arise about the main plot - huge questions - that are either answered in the bonus content or not at all.

Puzzle answers are just obvious enough to frustrate the player when their solution fails to work and then are told by the hint system to do exactly what they've done. Some very interesting puzzles are handled so poorly that instead of admiring the system you curse whoever wrote it.

Scenes provide enormous eyecandy that you cannot interact with
helpfulPercent: and then numerous repeated items that you CAN click but have no point. Achieving 100% completeion takes either several playthroughs or use of a guide (I can confidently say I would never have finished without a guide due to the unintuitiveness of some puzzles)
votesHelpful: without content changing a bit. The bonus content is decent but not a selling point.\n\nAll told
votesTotal: this game is at best a sub-par
votesFunny: disappointing waste of great potential. Not terrible
commentsCount: but could just be so much better."

reviewText: It's British, full of charm, doesn't take itself too seriously and the audio is great quality. It's essentially Monkey Island with dogs instead of people. It also actually plays on this old fossil of a computer! What's not to love?
Do you like adventure games? This is an adventure game.

A nice, humorous, light-hearted and kind of challenging point-and-click-adventure well worth your time. It's cartoonish but not childish, and funny in a less absurd Monkey Island-way (the pirate theme helps, too).
This game offers good laughs, some clever puzzles and hell of a good time, all for a very reasonable price. Ye'd be a fool not to check this one out.\n\nI wouldn't mind a sequel, too!

I enjoyed this game.  Graphics are quite pleasant, the voice acting is good, and it plays like it should.   I didn't find any game breaking bugs or any bugs that I recall.  I did get stuck in a couple areas for a while, though I was sure I tried the one thing that did work already before I looked it up.

All the good things said, it's short.  It doesn't take long to go through it, even with taking a while to figure something out.  The blacksmith shop should definitely have been used for something given the amount of detail that was put into it.

It is also fairly easy, but that is as good as it is bad.

If they made a Jolly Rover 2, I would buy it.
Pretty extensive storyline, with multiple different areas to explore. I wish I could go back and load my game at various previous points.

A fantastic point-and-click adventure with intuitive puzzles, great voice-acting, a huge number of branching choices, tons of collectables, and genuine humor. I can't recommend this enough! Monkey Island would be proud.

A charming homage to Monkey Island with its own kind of light-hearted, smile-inducing humor. Only hit a wall puzzle-wise once close to the end. Everything else made sense without always being too obvious.

A charming point-and-click adventure worthy of passing the time. It's quirky characters and innovative hint system will appeal to veterans and newbies of adventure games, but the appearance of some lazy puzzles and less-than-spectacular scriptwriting will only keep this title on the general average.

More or less a fairly wholesome and family friendly point and click game, with a pirate-dog theme.

There is no non-cartoon violence, only the mildest of sexual references, and one modest incident of swearing in the whole game.  Puzzles are mostly straightforward and the game is excessively generous with its hint system.  The game starts out a little underwhelming but once you get past the first zone it becomes quite a bit better.  Voice acting is passable, and the main character is a bit charming after awhile.  The biggest downfall of the game is probably that it isn't exceptionally amazing for a modern core gamer who expect a big wow factor, from graphics or production or epic story.  This isn't anything against it, it seems like a modest indie title and honestly it does nothing wrong.  It just means its not likely to get any amount of exposure.

I found the game charming and had a good time with it, and again its quite family-friendly so take that as you will.  Lasts about 4 hours or so, with no performance issues or bugs.  A more scalable resolution would have been nice too.  Probably would have been something I played as a kid.

A charming homage to Monkey Island with its own kind of light-hearted, smile-inducing humor. Only hit a wall puzzle-wise once close to the end. Everything else made sense without always being too obvious.

Fabulous game in my opinion, would play it again! :) It got a little frustrating at times if there was something you missed and got stuck (I don't like to cheat and use walkthroughs) but that's the same with most games of the genre hey?\nI like the fact each interactive item had a few different dialogues when clicked, I think I spent quite some time going through them all on everything! (though each one is voiced not just text, so for some I suppose it could become annoying, however a simple click skips his speech).\nIf you like a bit of an adventure, collecting items and putting them together for a purpose, a bit of voodoo lol, or just the fact the game is based on pirates, I recommend this game to you!

This isn't anything against it, it seems like a modest indie title and honestly it does nothing wrong.  It just means its not likely to get any amount of exposure.

I found the game charming and had a good time with it, and again its quite family-friendly so take that as you will.  Lasts about 4 hours or so, with no performance issues or bugs.  A more scalable resolution would have been nice too.  Probably would have been something I played as a kid.

A solid indie p&c adventure game that's admittedly just slightly rough around the edges in most segments, but charming and pleasant enough to drive you to the finish, despite some tedium here and there. You'll see some very inspired design visually and mechanically, you'll see some less inspired in the same category. Same with the writing / the humor. The voice acting for some characters is surprisingly great. It's quite short (playing time was @ 3 hours when I'd finished it first on Steam - I HAVE finished it before once, years and years ago, but retained almost no memory of the gameplay... apart from some vague memories about the voodoo mechanic, which might've knocked several minutes off the game time now I guess - but you won't mind. Unlocking the commentary might give an excuse to OCD-ish / completist players to do it all over again, especially since you'll likely miss (or, hopefully less likely, use) some of the crackers and the coins - which otherwise unlock music, art and character bios as you collect them. I'm not 100% sure I'd have done it if I hadn't missed the second to last coin in the game, but hey...\n\nAnyway, it's a fun little game, recommended to fans of the genre... and people who dig the idea of dog pirates and find it cute. :)
If you enjoyed 1990s Lucasfilm adventure games then you'll definitely enjoy this.
This is a fun little game. No replayability whatsoever but it does not need replayability. Playing the gmae through once is just fine and it is an enjoyable experience.
